titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Finished writing the third number of the Gazette—and wrote another letter— Walking this afternoon I met Countess Brühl— Pauline Neale and the Miss Brown’s called to see Mrs: A.

2. Called this morning at Mr: Schickler’s Compting house— Afterwards upon Mr: Richard with whom I transacted my business— Sent a bill for £500 to Mr: King— Letters to my father & my brother enclosed to him— Mrs: O’Farrill call’d and spent a couple of hours with Mrs: A— this afternoon.

3. Read a sermon of Tillotson, upon the education of children. Received a letter from the Minister Count Alvensleben, informing me that the king has fixed the day after to-morrow, to give me audience at Potsdam—for taking leave— Wrote immediately to Mr: Massow, requesting him to take the orders of the queen, when she would grant her Audience— Went to Mr: Cohen’s—a play performed— Saw only the first act of Les fausses confidences; the heat was so excessive I could not stand it. Remainder of the Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Took Kinnaird with me— Play’d Casino, with the prince; Madame de Hordt, and Madame Grappendorf.

4. At one o’clock, afternoon, my child was baptized by Mr: Proby, the chaplain of the english legation. Lord Carysfort and myself were the god-fathers; and Lady Carysfort god-mother. Mrs: Adams was not well enough to be present, and the ceremony was therefore made as private as possible; having only the persons present absolutely necessary, and the family.— The child’s name is George Washington; and I implore the favour of almighty God, that he may live, and never prove unworthy of it.— Walk’d with Lord Carysfort under the linden, untill dinner time.— Mrs: Reynal left us.

5. Between four and five o’clock this morning I left town, and went with Whitcomb to Potsdam. At ten The king’s carriage came and took me at the Inn. the Minister Alvensleben went with me, and introduced me to the Audience. The king’s Aid de camp, Kökeritz was the only person in the Antichamber.— I delivered my letter of recall, and took leave— The king told me he had been pleased at my residence here, and was well satisfied with my conduct— At eleven o’clock I had the Audience of the Queen— Was introduced by Mr: Massow— Countess Voss and two Maids of honour were with her— She repeated nearly what the king had said, with less appearance of saying mere formalities— Talk’d about Silesia, Switzerland, Sea-voyages and so forth— In less than half an hour all was over— I return’d to the inn; wrote a letter to my brother, to pass the time— Dined between two and three, and at four set out, upon my return to Berlin. We reach’d home about 7 in the evening.

6. Miss Bischoffwerder, Mrs: Brown and Pauline Neale called to see Mrs: Adams— Spent the Evening and supped at Lord Carysfort’s, with a large company. The Russians among the rest— Play’d whist with Madame de Reck—Countess Henry Brühl, and Count Baudissin, the Danish Minister— Almost midnight when I came home.

7. At half past twelve, I went to Monbijou, and had an Audience to take leave of the queen mother— Saw the prince and princess of Orange there.— Countess Henry Brühl called to see Mrs: A. in the afternoon— Walk’d in the park.

8. At 5 this afternoon, I call’d on Count Alvensleben, who delivered me the letter of recredence from the king; and offered me the usual present of a box, which I declined to accept— Lady Carysfort called to see Mrs: Adams— And Miss Esdorff likewise— Garlike took leave, for Petersburg.

9. Was very unwell with a rheumatism in the breast for two or three hours this forenoon— It pass’d off however— I believe it was owing to my having used thin cloathing the last two days— Met Lord Carysfort walking with Mr: Casamajor his new Secretary, arrived this morning.— Letters to the Secy: of State, and to my brother, enclosed to Mr: Murray. (5. Et. Fr.)

10. Read a sermon of Tillotson— The second upon the education of children. Dined at Lord Carysfort’s— The two brothers Messrs: Fagel, and Count Gallatin were the only company besides the family. Countess Brühl called in the afternoon to see Mrs: A.

11. Was at a diplomatic dinner of thirty persons at Baron Krüdener’s— Lady Carysfort, and Fanny Brown called on Mrs: A— This day she walk’d with help, and great difficulty across the room; for the first time since her illness. Walk in the park towards Evening.

12. Up very early this morning and took a walk in the park before breakfast. Letter to the Secretary of State, enclosing that of recredence from the king of Prussia, forwarded to Mr: Pitcairn.— Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Whist with Madame de Reck, Count Goltz and Mr: Sydow.

13. Walk in the park again before breakfast— Greatest part of the day employed in making out the Catalogue of my books, and packing them up to send away— Return’d to my chamber— Mrs: A. went out for the first time.

14. Rainy morning. Walk’d, notwithstanding.— Finish’d my Catalogue of books.— Writing almost all the forenoon. Was obliged to return again at night to the chamber I have occupied these six weeks— Mrs: A— had visits from Countess Neale and Madame Borch— Fanny Brown &c.

15. The weather is again fine, and I improve it to walk early in the morning— Walk’d again in the park towards evening.— Pauline Neale called to see Mrs: Adams, who continues very unwell, and whose recovery, we are not allowed to hope for a long time at best.

16. Took my morning and evening walks in the park. This morning, Mr: Welsh left us for Amsterdam, whence he intends to embark for America— Wrote to my father by him (Gaz: N. 4.)— Mrs: A. dined with me— The first time for many weeks— Margaret Brown called upon her— I am reading Volney’s travels in Syria and Egypt.

17. Weather excessively warm— Took my two walks— Read a sermon of Tillotson— The third upon the education of children, and the best of his sermons I have yet read— It is truly eloquent: written with a warmth and animation of style and manner, more resembling the french preachers than his ordinary way.— Began to write some reflections upon reading.

18. The weather extremely warm. Find myself left without an occupation, and without the resolution & perseverance to give myself one— Mrs: A—’s health, varying from day to day, between bad and worse keeps me in a crucifying state of suspense— My own health suffers from it in proportion.
19. Bathed this morning in the river, after walking about three miles for a proper spot. I try the cold bath as a species of exercise, and as a tonic— The weather excessively hot.

20. Bathed again in the river— First day of the reviews; but I did not go— Saw the troops at the gate of Brandenburg as I pass’d— Dined at Count Alvensleben’s, with a company of about forty persons— A diplomatic dinner— Walk in the evening— Return’d to my chamber— Finished Volney’s account of Egypt & Syria; much pleased with it.

21. The reviews continue— Bathed in the river— Cold in the morning; but grew warm the whole day— Evening at Lord Carysfort’s— Play’d whist with Madame de Heinitz, Countess Haugwitz, and Mr: Engeström— Did not stay to supper— Finished the essay on reading.

22. Weather very warm— Dined with the Portuguese Minister, the Chevalier de Correa; General d’Escars, Dr: Brown and Mr: Richard, were the only company— Margaret Brown called on Mrs: A— in the afternoon— Walked in the evening with Genl: d’Escars & Mr: Richard.
23. Wrote several short letters— But I am bringing all my correspondence to a close. In the Evening at Court—the review Ball— Weather excessively warm.

24. Read a Sermon of Tillotson— Upon the advantages of early piety. Margaret Brown called to see Mrs: A— in the morning, and Mr: Kinnaird after dinner— Heat Excessive— Thunder-showers threaten and blow over.

25. Mrs: Brown called upon Mrs: A— this afternoon. I met Lord Carysfort and Mr: Proby, walking with Mr: Fagel— Walk’d with them— Lord C. and his family go this day to Charlottenburg.— Heat continues extreme.

26. Finished reading Volney’s travels in Egypt and Syria; which I find full of amusement and of information— The religious opinions for which he has in later times been so noted, are scarcely perceptible in this book. The condition of the people in both provinces he represents as extremely miserable, and imputes it all to their form of government— To the principle of despotism, which from the heart of the empire, the Sultan, pervades not only every vein and artery but every nerve and sinew every cartilage and bone of the Turk, and destroys all security for property.— Mrs: O’Farrell called this evening to see Mrs: A.

27. Mr: Proby called upon me this forenoon— Rode out after dinner with Mrs: A— on the road to Potsdam, as far as Schöneberg. Rainy evening, and a thunder shower— Reading Schiller’s history of the 30. years war.— Write lazily.

28. Rained most of the night— Walked out this morning, but did not bathe. Introduced Mr: Casamajor and Mr: Proby to the Casino, and proposed them to be balloted next Thursday.— Went to the play and saw Bayard, a tragedy of Kotzebue’s— The house so full I was obliged to stand in the pit.

29. Bathe again in the morning,—and in the Evening took a long walk— Am analysing Gentz’s book upon the origin and character of the war against the french revolution; but an irresistible indolence is creeping upon me, and I have nearly done writing.

30. Letter to my brother enclosed to Mr: Bourne, to go by Mr: Welsh—likewise to Pitcairn to engage us lodgings at Hamburg and a passage to New-York. The two Miss Brown’s called here in the afternoon: Mrs: A— was gone out— She is yet quite unwell.— Letters and a pamphlet from Mr: King.

31. Read this morning in Tillotson’s rule of faith— Mrs: A— went to Charlottenburg, to call upon Lady Carysfort, and stay’d there to dinner— I went out myself; and in the evening walked in to town. General Stamford and his lady, and Mr: Deluc called while we were there—

Day. Rise a short time before six Walk about two miles out of town and bathe in the Spree; then walk home to breakfast— It takes two hours and a half— Breakfast at 9. Write, as much as visitors and other interruptions allow me, untill two— Dine— After dinner, sit with my wife, or read untill 7. then walk again about an hour & a half— Take my supper between 9 and 10. And go to bed at eleven.
